msDesc.physDesc: This letter is one page long. The words “Poetry (Monroe)” are written in pencil in the top center of the page.

div.p: I am sending you the best poem I have ever written. But whether you will think so or not is, of course, problematical. It is a kind of companion piece to "Malmaison", which, I am thankful to say, has met with considerable success. It is, of course, in polyphonic, and it is very long. But as you have already printed one play taking up a whole number, perhaps you will not object to taking part of a number with this. I intended to wait until I came out to Chicago, and read it to you, but now that I am not coming until the end of February, I think I will send this now.

In March it will be six months since you have published anything of mine, and as I am going to be in Chicago lecturing the end of February and the first of March, it would be a convenience to me and timely for you if you print this in your March number.
I hope you are succeeding in getting your money all right for next year. I have not promised anything yet, because I wanted to see how you were going. We will talk it over when I get to Chicago.

I am enclosing a review of me by Fletcher, which he has sent and asked me to place. If you like it, he will be glad to have you print it — needless to say, so will I. If you do not like it, or if somebody else has already reviewed my book, please return it to me.
